verses.text: An oracle of transgression speaks within the heart of the wicked; there is no fear of God before his eyes.
verses.comment: The psalm begins with a prophetic insight or 'oracle' into human sinfulness. Paul quotes this verse in Romans 3:18, linking original sin and the necessity for grace. Notice the 'fear of God' missing—a recurring theme in Catholic spirituality, notably in the Seven Gifts of the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: For he flatters himself in his own eyes, that his iniquity cannot be found out and hated.
verses.comment: Self-deception leads one away from repentance. Catholic tradition emphasizes examination of conscience, which helps uncover hidden sins, guiding believers towards confession and reconciliation.

verses.text: The words of his mouth are wickedness and deceit; he has ceased to act wisely and do good.
verses.comment: Sin affects speech and actions. Catholic teaching affirms that both faith and works express true piety, aligning with James 2:17.

verses.text: He plots wickedness on his bed; he sets himself on a path that is not good; he does not reject evil.
verses.comment: The psalmist describes a willful persistence in evil. The Catholic understanding of free will includes the power to cooperate with or resist grace.

verses.text: Your steadfast love, O LORD, reaches to the heavens, your faithfulness to the skies.
verses.comment: God’s love and faithfulness are incomparably vast. This echoes the Catholic belief in God’s infinite mercy, often reflected in devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus.

verses.text: Your righteousness is like the mountains of God; your judgments are like the great deep; O LORD, you preserve man and beast.
verses.comment: God’s justice is both majestic and mysterious. The preservation of all creatures highlights sacramental realities, such as blessing of animals and the Catholic vision of creation redeemed.

verses.text: How precious is your steadfast love, O God! The children of mankind take refuge in the shadow of your wings.
verses.comment: The image of shelter under God’s wings hints at sacramental protection, prefiguring Christ's words in Matt. 23:37. Catholics read this as God gathering people under the Church, his body.

verses.text: They feast on the abundance of your house, and you give them drink from the river of your delights.
verses.comment: The imagery of feasting and drinking from God’s house is eucharistic; Catholics see here a veiled prophecy of the Eucharist, the true feast and living water (John 6:35).

verses.text: For with you is the fountain of life; in your light we see light.
verses.comment: A strong Christological theme—Jesus as the light and source of life (John 8:12). Catholic theology affirms that Christ himself is the font of life, especially through sacramental grace.

verses.text: Continue your steadfast love to those who know you, and your righteousness to the upright in heart.
verses.comment: Perseverance in grace is a Catholic doctrine reinforced here. The upright in heart must continually seek God, echoing the need for ongoing conversion and sanctification.

verses.text: Let not the foot of arrogance come upon me, nor the hand of the wicked drive me away.
verses.comment: Praying against pride and evil, the psalmist anticipates the humility needed for sanctification—a key virtue in Catholic asceticism.

verses.text: There the evildoers have fallen; they have been thrown down and cannot rise.
verses.comment: Divine judgment is final upon the unrepentant. Catholic teaching on mortal sin and final perseverance is suggested: without grace, there is no rising from spiritual death.
